CHAPTER 1. Loomings.72806932467611110510346

Call me Ishmael. Some years ago—never mind how long precisely—having9710810932115109101468310932101114321038212101101321051001041191081103211499115108821297105103
little or no money in my purse, and nothing particular to interest me1051161011113211110911012110532121112114101321103211110411032971169910811411632110101101116109
on shore, I thought I would sail about a little and see the watery part11011511110132321041171043232111108329710897111116971081161083211032101321043297101121112114
of the world. It is a way I have of driving off the spleen and102116101119114100321161053232973232971011113211411811032102321043211210111097100
regulating the circulation. Whenever I find myself growing grim about1011179710510311610199114117971051103210411011811473102110321211011021031111051031031053298117
the mouth; whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul; whenever1043211111659119101101101321161053232971123211412210832111101981141053212111511759119101101101
I find myself involuntarily pausing before coffin warehouses, and321051001091151083211011111711611410832971151103210111110199102105329710111111511532110
bringing up the rear of every funeral I meet; and especially whenever114110105103117321043210111411132118114321171019732321011163211032115101105108121119101101101
my hypos get such an upper hand of me, that it requires a strong moral1211041121151031161159932110117112114104110321021094411697321161141131051013232116111103109114108
principle to prevent me from deliberately stepping into the street, and11411010510832111112101101116109321141091001089811411610832116112105103105116321043211610111632110
methodically knocking people’s hats off—then, I account it high time to10110410099108121107111107110321011121011151041163210282121041103232991111103211610410332105101116
get to sea as soon as I can. This is my substitute for pistol and ball.101321111159797321111109732329746841053211510932117115105117101102114112115111321103297108
With a philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I10510497112105111111104991081021111141153297111116114119321051151083211211010411511511110032
quietly take to the ship. There is nothing surprising in this. If they11710110832971011163210432104112321041143211511011610510311511411411511032110116105467332104121
but knew it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other,11732110119105449710911532108321013211011610111410010310144115109321051011113211610144
cherish very nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.10411411532101121110971083210432971011021011051033211197100321043299973210510410946

There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by10411432111321151211173211011797321051211113210432971041161111153210111610011411710098
wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs—commerce surrounds it with her1041141013211573100973211510132121991141081141011159910910199321171141171003211611911632101
surf. Right and left, the streets take you waterward. Its extreme11710232105104321103210111632104321161011163297101121117119116114971003211632120114109
downtown is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by waves, and1111101111101053210432971161144411910110111697321111083211110110532971041009832971014497100
cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of sight of11110810098321141011014411910510497102119104117115112101105117321011011111161113210510432102

Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon. Go from Corlears10599109109117971011161019911632102971001011093297981163210210111011146713211410967114101114
Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall, northward. What111107116321111101051158310544971001021113210411010132121871051019710832111116119114468797

I was a good Christian; born and bred in the bosom of the infallible3297323211110067114115105110321111109710098101321101161019811510911132104321109710898101

In behalf of the dignity of whaling, I would fain advance naught but1109810410832102116101100103105121111321041081104473119117100102105321009799329710311698116

It is well known that at the coronation of kings and queens, even11610532101108107111110116973211611610199114110116111321021071101159710011310111044101101

precisely—who knows? Certain I am, however, that a king’s head is114991151088212104321101196367114971107397441041191181143210411697107110821732101100105
solemnly oiled at his coronation, even as a head of salad. Can it be,1111011101211111081009732105321111119710511032118110973232101100111329797466711010532101
though, that they anoint it with a view of making its interior run10411710432104116116101321101051161053210510497118101321021091071103211632110101105114114110
well, as they anoint machinery? Much might be ruminated here,1011083211511610132110105116109991051011213211710410910311698321171059710132101101
concerning the essential dignity of this regal process, because in1119911410510311610110111511010510810010310512111132104115114103108112111101115321019711532110
common life we esteem but meanly and contemptibly a fellow who anoints1111091101081023210110111610132117321011101219710099110101112105108323210110811911911197111110115
his hair, and palpably smells of that anointing. In truth, a mature man10532971143211032971129812111510110832102116973211010511611046733211411644971091161143297
who uses hair-oil, unless medicinally, that man has probably got a104321151151041054510544117108115321011051059710844116973297329732114989812110311697

The chief mate of the Pequod was Starbuck, a native of Nantucket, and a104321041013297101111321043210111710011911583979899449711011611832102781101171071163211032

With memories like these in him, and, moreover, given to a certain10510410910911410132105101116101101105321054497100321111011181143210510132111979911497110

But were the coming narrative to reveal in any instance, the complete117321011011161019910911032971141161183211111411897321109712110511597994411610199109108116

Stubb was the second mate. He was a native of Cape Cod; and hence,11698329732104321011111001091164672329732329710510111132971016710032110321019944

Next: how shall we define the whale, by his obvious externals, so as10111632111321041083210110010211032104321041084498321053298105117321201011101084411532115

BOOK III. (_Duodecimo_), CHAPTER 1. (_Huzza Porpoise_).—This is the797573733295117100991099544676584824932951171223211111210510141821210411510532104
common porpoise found almost all over the globe. The name is of my own11110911011211411111532111110321081111169710811110132104321089846841011101093211511132121111110

In this one matter, Ahab seemed no exception to most American whale1101161053211032971161143210498115101101321111019911210511011632111116651011059732104108

I, Ishmael, was one of that crew; my shouts had gone up with the rest;447310497108329732110321021169732114119321211151111163297321111011173210510411610111411559

For some time past, though at intervals only, the unaccompanied,1113211110111610932971163210411710497321101011181083211012132104321109911111211010144
secluded White Whale had haunted those uncivilized seas mostly101108100100871051018797101104100104117116100116111101117991181081221001159732111116121
frequented by the Sperm Whale fishermen. But not all of them knew of11411310111610098321043211211432104108321051041141014666116110116971081113210410910710132102
his existence; only a few of them, comparatively, had knowingly seen1053212011510199591111083232101321021161014499109979710510112132973211011911010832101110

along solitary latitudes, so as seldom or never for a whole twelvemonth10811032111105971211081161161001153211197321011001091113210110132111323210410832119108101111116
or more on a stretch, to encounter a single news-telling sail of any1141091143211097115114116104321111019911711611497115110108321011151161081051031151053210297121

of the times of sailing from home; all these, with other circumstances,102116101116109115111329710811032114109104109599710811610110132105104111104114991141171159799115
direct and indirect, long obstructed the spread through the whole105101116971001051001149944108110329811611711610011610111511497321041111033210432104108
world-wide whaling-fleet of the special individualizing tidings1111084510510111997105103102101116111321043211299973211010510511710812211032105105103

CHAPTER 42. The Whiteness of the Whale.72806932503210432104116110115321021161018797101

What the white whale was to Ahab, has been hinted; what, at times, he104116116101119105101119971011191151163210498329732101110104110101591199744973210510144104
was to me, as yet remains unsaid.973211110944973210132101971103211097100

Aside from those more obvious considerations touching Moby Dick, which1151003211410911611110110911432981051173211111510011411611111511611710411032111121689944119105104
could not but occasionally awaken in any man’s soul some alarm, there11110832111321173299971051101081219797101321109712110911011511511732111101979710932104114

several consecutive minutes. But I must be content with only one more10110197321111159911611832105117101466611673109115321019911010111611911632110121111101109114

by which you will not fail to see, that not only is the most marvellous12111910510412111711910832111329710811632101441169732111321101211053210432111116109114101108117
event in this book corroborated by plain facts of the present day, but11811032110116105321111079911411111197101321211129711010299115111321043211411511032974498116

so that for the millionth time we say amen with Solomon—Verily there is1111169732111321043210510811111632105101119329732109110119116321111111118212101105121116101101105
nothing new under the sun.1111041103210132110101321043211746

In the sixth Christian century lived Procopius, a Christian magistrate110116101115120104671141151051109911011712110811810080111111105115323210410511697329710511697101

But what is a _Gam?_ You might wear out your index-finger running up1173210411610532327110995891171091031161199732117321111141051001201021101013211711011032112

GAM. NOUN—_A social meeting of two_ (_or more_) _Whaleships, generally654678858212651159997321011161103210211611132951141091149532879710110411244103110114108121
on a cruising-ground; when, after exchanging hails, they exchange110979911711511045114117100321041103210210132120104110105103104105115321041211019997103
visits by boats’ crews: the two captains remaining, for the time, on10510511598321111168217991011153210432119329711610511511410910510510332111321043210510132110
board of one ship, and the two chief mates on the other._11111432102111101115105449710011610111611199105102109116115111321043211610146

There is another little item about Gamming which must not be forgotten10411432115971111041141081161083211610997111116711091051031191051041091153211132101102114111116110
here. All professions have their own little peculiarities of detail; so10110132108321141021151051103297101116101114111110108116108321011171051141161013210210011610559115
has the whale fishery. In a pirate, man-of-war, or slave ship, when the97321043210410832105104114467332321059710132974510211911432114115971011151054411910132104
captain is rowed anywhere in his boat, he always sits in the stern97116105321151141191009712110411432110104115989744104321089711511511632110116101115101110
sheets on a comfortable, sometimes cushioned seat there, and often104101115111323211110211497108441151091161091159911510511010011597321041144497100111116110
steers himself with a pretty little milliner’s tiller decorated with116101115104109101102119116323211411612110811610832105108110114115116108101321011119710132105104
gay cords and ribbons. But the whale-boat has no seat astern, no sofa97321111003211032105981104666116116101119971019897329732111115973211510111032111115102
of that sort whatever, and no tiller at all. High times indeed, if10211697321111161199710110144971001103210510811497321084672103321051013211010110032102
whaling captains were wheeled about the water on castors like gouty old104108110329711610511511911432104101101329811732104329710132110991151111151081073211111632108
aldermen in patent chairs. And as for a tiller, the whale-boat never10810110911010532971011169997114466510097321113232105108114321043210410845111116110118114
admits of any such effeminacy; and therefore as in gamming a complete100105115111321103211710410110210911099599710011610110111110197321101031091051039799109108116
boat’s crew must leave the ship, and hence as the boat steerer or1111161159910132117116108971011161011151054497100104110101973210432111116115101114114111
harpooneer is of the number, that subordinate is the steersman upon the97112111101114105321021161011101091014411697321171111001101163211511610111510111410911011711132104
occasion, and the captain, having no place to sit in, is pulled off to9997105110321103210432971161054410411811032111112971011163210532110321151121081013210232111
his visit all standing like a pine tree. And often you will notice that105321051053210832116110105103108107323210510111610146651001111161101211171191083211110510111697
being conscious of the eyes of the whole visible world resting on him1011103211111510511732102116101101101321021161011191111011181159810111911410011411510510311132105

CHAPTER 54. The Town-Ho’s Story.728069325232104321111107282173211611446

(_As told at the Golden Inn._)951151161083211611610171108101321104641

The Cape of Good Hope, and all the watery region round about there, is10432971011113211110072112449710097108116101119116114321011051101141171009711111611610110132115
much like some noted four corners of a great highway, where you meet11710410810732111101110116100102117321111101143210297103101116104103119121321041143211132101116
more travellers than in any other part.111101116971011081143210411010532110321161013297116

It was not very long after speaking the Goney that another116119115110116118114321111039711611411510110711032104321111013210411697111104114
homeward-bound whaleman, the Town-Ho,* was encountered. She was manned1111019710098117100119971019744116101841194511142119115101991171161141003210432973297110100
almost wholly by Polynesians. In the short gam that ensued she gave us10811111611911110832121801081101159711532110116101115111116103109116973211011710011510110311832115
strong news of Moby Dick. To some the general interest in the White1161111031101193210277983210510732111115109321043210110197321101011011161053210432104116
Whale was now wildly heightened by a circumstance of the Town-Ho’s104108329732111321051001211041051041011013212197991141171159799321021161018411945111115
story, which seemed obscurely to involve with the whale a certain116114441191051041151011013298991141083211110511810810111911632104321041083232101116105
wondrous, inverted visitation of one of those so called judgments of11110011111532110101116100118115116116111321021111011113210411532111991081013211710310111632102
God which at times are said to overtake some men. This latter11132104993211611610911597101115105321111111011161073211110110911032104115108116101
circumstance, with its own particular accompaniments, forming what may10599109116110101321051041051151111101121141051179732991111121101091101153211110911032104116109121
be called the secret part of the tragedy about to be narrated, never101991081013210432101114116112114321021161011169710112197111116116321011101149710144110118114
reached the ears of Captain Ahab or his mates. For that secret part of10199101321043297115111329711610532104981113210532971014670114116973210111411611211432102
the story was unknown to the captain of the Town-Ho himself. It was the10432116114329732110110119321111161019911297110111321043211111072321051151084673329732104
private property of three confederate white seamen of that ship, one of11411811632114112114121111321041013211110210011411632104116321011091101113210411611510544111101111
whom, it seems, communicated it to Tashtego with Romish injunctions of10410932116115101115321111091109911610010532111841151161033210510482109115321101179910511032102
secrecy, but the following night Tashtego rambled in his sleep, and101114994498116116101102108111105103110103116841151161033297981013211010411511510111232110
revealed so much of it in that way, that when he was wakened he could101101108100115321171041113211610532104116119121321041161191013210111911511910711010010432111108
not well withhold the rest. Nevertheless, so potent an influence did111321011081191161041083210432101116321011011161011011153211111211611032110105102117110101100100
this thing have on those seamen in the Pequod who came to the full104115116105103104118321101161111011159710132110116101801131113210432971011163210432117108
knowledge of it, and by such a strange delicacy, to call it so, were11011910110332102105449710098321171049711511411010110010899994411632971081053211132101101
they governed in this matter, that they kept the secret among10412110311811410132110116105329711611432104116116101321011161161011159910132109110
themselves so that it never transpired abaft the Pequod’s main-mast.1041091011181151153210411610532101101321141101121141009797116116101801131118217329711010911546
Interweaving in its proper place this darker thread with the story as110101119971051031053211632114112114112971011161053297107114116114973210510411610111511112197

The whale-line is only two-thirds of an inch in thickness. At first1043210410845105101105321101211161111161051003210297321101041053210499110115466532105115

According to the invariable usage of the fishery, the whale-boat pushes9911110011032111116101105118114971083211510332102116101102115101121321043210410845111116112115101

oar, the one known as the harpooneer-oar. Now it needs a strong,97441161011111011071111109732104329711211110111411111432111321161101011159711511411044
nervous arm to strike the first iron into the fish; for often, in what1011181173211432111115114107321043210511532114110105116321043210510432111321021014410532104116
is called a long dart, the heavy implement has to be flung to the11599108101323211110310011444116101104971211051121011011161041151163210110211710311632104

CHAPTER 63. The Crotch.72806932513210432114116104

Out of the trunk, the branches grow; out of them, the twigs. So, in11732102116101116117107321043211411010411510311159111116111321041093210432119103468344105
productive subjects, grow the chapters.1141009910510111598101116441031113210432104112101115

The crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent mention.104321141161049710810010011632110971121011051173297101100115114101321101011011001103210111611146
It is a notched stick of a peculiar form, some two feet in length,11610532321119910132116993210297112991089732111109321111011161111021013211010811011644
which is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard gunwale near the10499321151121141011009910811412110511511410132110111116101115979897100103110971011109732104
bow, for the purpose of furnishing a rest for the wooden extremity of111441021141161011121141111011113211711011510510397114115321113210432111100110101116101105121111
the harpoon, whose other naked, barbed end slopingly projects from the10432971121114411911110111110411411010710032979810010110011511110510312111211110111632114109116101
prow. Thereby the weapon is instantly at hand to its hurler, who1141193210411498321043210111211010532110116110108321161041103211110511510411410144119111
snatches it up as readily from its rest as a backwoodsman swings his11011610411510532112973210110010832114109105115114115321159798991191111159732119110115104115
rifle from the wall. It is customary to have two harpoons reposing in105108321141091161011191084673321159911511197121116329710111611110411411111032101111105103105
the crotch, respectively called the first and second irons.1043211411610432101112991051011219910810132104321051153211032101111100105111115

But these two harpoons, each by its own cord, are both connected with11732104115321193297112111115329710498321163211932111100321143211110499110101116100119116
the line; the object being this: to dart them both, if possible, one1043210510132104329810111698105103116105581163297116116101321111043210211211510510844111101
instantly after the other into the same whale; so that if, in the110116110108321021013210432116101321101111161011151093210410859115321041161054410532104
coming drag, one should draw out, the other may still retain a hold. It11110510310097441111011151111083211411911111632104321161013297321161083210197110971041084673
is a doubling of the chances. But it very often happens that owing to1159710011710811032102116101999799115321173211611811432102101329711211032104116111105103116
the instantaneous, violent, convulsive running of the whale upon10432110116110971011174411811110111632111118108105101114110105103111321043210410832112110
receiving the first iron, it becomes impossible for the harpooneer,10110111811032104321051153211411032116989910911510511211510510832111321043297112111101114
however lightning-like in his movements, to pitch the second iron into11110110132105104110110451051011053210532111101101116441163210599321043210111110010511132110111
him. Nevertheless, as the second iron is already connected with the1054678118114104108115449732104321011111001051113211597114971219911010111610011911632104
line, and the line is running, hence that weapon must, at all events,1051013211032104321051011053211711011044104110101116973210111211010911544973210832118110115
be anticipatingly tossed out of the boat, somehow and somewhere; else101971169911211611010832111115100111116111321043211111632111101111321103211110110411459101115
the most terrible jeopardy would involve all hands. Tumbled into the104321111161161141051083210111211412111911710010511810810197108104110115321179810132110111116101
water, it accordingly is in such cases; the spare coils of box line971014410532991111001101083211510532117104991151153210432112114321111083210298120108110
(mentioned in a preceding chapter) making this feat, in most instances,1091101051101001053232114991001103210411210141109107110321041151029744105321111161051159799115
prudently practicable. But this critical act is not always unattended114100110108321149910597108466611611610532114116991089711610532111321089711511797116110101
with the saddest and most fatal casualties.105104116101115100101116971001091153297973297117108105115

Furthermore: you must know that when the second iron is thrown11711610110911458121117109115321101191169732104110116101115991103211411010532104111110

or cutting them, and making a prodigious sensation in all directions.1149911610510311610144971001091071103232114100103111115115110971051101053210832105101116111115
Nor, in general, is it possible to secure it again until the whale is1114410532101101974410532116112115105108321111159911432116979711011711610811610111997101105
fairly captured and a corpse.9711412199112117101321103232111112101

CHAPTER 65. The Whale as a Dish.7280693253321043210410832115976811546

That mortal man should feed upon the creature that feeds his lamp, and,104116109114973297321041171001021013211211011610199101116114321041161021011151041151081094497100
like Stubb, eat him by his own light, as you may say; this seems so1051018311798329732105321211041151111101081031163211512111710912111512132104115115101115115
outlandish a thing that one must needs go a little into the history and117108110105104971161051031169732110321171161101011151033232105116101105116321043210511611432110
philosophy of it.10410811511212111132116

It is upon record, that three centuries ago the tongue of the Right1161053211211011499114441169732104101321011161141013210332104321111031011113210432105104
Whale was esteemed a great delicacy in France, and commanded large1041083297321151011091009710310111610010899993211070979944971009910997100100108114101
prices there. Also, that in Henry VIIIth’s time, a certain cook of the11499115116101101321081113210411610532101114327373104115116109449799114971109911132102116101
court obtained a handsome reward for inventing an admirable sauce to be1111143298971101009710411011510932101971001021141051181101051039732100105971083297993211198
eaten with barbacued porpoises, which, you remember, are a species of97101321051049811497117100112114111115115321049944121117114109109101449710197115101105115111
whale. Porpoises, indeed, are to this day considered fine eating. The1041084680114111115115321101011003211432111116105329732111115100114100102110329710510332104
meat is made into balls about the size of billiard balls, and being10111610532971011051163297108329811732104321051011113210510897100981081153211032101110
well seasoned and spiced might be taken for turtle-balls or veal balls.101108115971111013211032112991001091031169832971013211132117116101981081151113210110898108115
The old monks of Dunfermline were very fond of them. They had a great10432108321111073210268110101109105101119114321011211021103210211610146841013297323211497
porpoise grant from the crown.11111210510110397116102111321043211411946

The fact is, that among his hunters at least, the whale would by all1043297116105441169732109110321053211711611432116108971163210432104108321111083212197108
hands be considered a noble dish, were there not so much of him; but9710032101991101051011013232111108321051043210110111610110111011611532117104111321055998116
when you come to sit down before a meat-pie nearly one hundred feet10411012111799109321111151161001193210111110197109974510532101114121111101104110114100102101

CHAPTER 72. The Monkey-Rope.728069325032104321111071218211246

In the tumultuous business of cutting-in and attending to a whale,1101161011161091081171173211710510111511132117116110451109710097116110105103116323210410844
there is much running backwards and forwards among the crew. Now hands104114321151099932117110110329710797100321103211111911411597111103116101991014678119104110115
are wanted here, and then again hands are wanted there. There is no114329711610010411444971001161013210310532971003211432971161001161011013210411432115110

to be done everywhere. It is much the same with him who endeavors the11198321111011011011211041144673321151099932104329710111911632105321043211010111811432104
description of the scene. We must now retrace our way a little. It was101991051161113210211610111510110132101109115321113210111499321173297323210511610132116119115

CHAPTER 84. Pitchpoling.7280693252321059911210811046

To make them run easily and swiftly, the axles of carriages are111109107321041091141101011151083211032119102108441161019710811511132971149710132114

First: Being horizontal in its position, the Leviathan’s tail acts in a10511558661051031041141221109732110105115112115116111441161017611897104110115116105329911510532

All whaleboats carry certain curious contrivances, originally invented1083210410898971159911412199114971109911411111599110114118110101441111051059710832110101116100

other’s grain at right angles; a line of considerable length is then116101821732114105321161141031169710310159971081103210299110105101971083210110310410532104110
attached to the middle of this block, and the other end of the line11697104100116321043210510010111132104115981111073211032104321161013211032102116101108110
being looped, it can in a moment be fastened to a harpoon. It is1011103211111210032116991101053232111101116983297116110100116323297112111467332115
chiefly among gallied whales that this drugg is used. For then, more10410110832109110329710810132104108115116973210411510011710310532115100321113210411032111101

CHAPTER 88. Schools and Schoolmasters.728069325632991111083211032991111089711611446

CHAPTER 89. Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish.7280693257329711670115321103211111545105104

The allusion to the waif and waif-poles in the last chapter but one,1043210811710511011632104329710297100119105451111013211011610110811532104112101321173211044
necessitates some account of the laws and regulations of the whale1011011151161161151151093299111110321021161011081193211032101117971051103210211610111997101
fishery, of which the waif may be deemed the grand symbol and badge.10510411444111321049932104329710210912198321011091001161011039710011510911132110329710346

It frequently happens that when several ships are cruising in company,11610210111711010832971121103210411611910132101101973210411232114321141051051031053211111211044
a whale may be struck by one vessel, then escape, and be finally killed3210410832973210111511499321211111011181151014411610132115971013211032101102110108121107108101
and captured by another vessel; and herein are indirectly comprised11032971161141009832110116101321011151083211032101101110971011051001149910832111112105101
many minor contingencies, all partaking of this one grand feature. For9712110911011499110105103110105115321083297116107110321021161053211032114110321011161144670114
example,—after a weary and perilous chase and capture of a whale, the12010910844971161149711997121971001121141081173210411532110329711611432102971199710132104
body may get loose from the ship by reason of a violent storm; and111121109121103116108111101102111321043210411298321011151101113232105108110321161145997100
drifting far away to leeward, be retaken by a second whaler, who, in a114102105103102114979732111108101971003210111411610711098323210111110011997101441191113211097
calm, snugly tows it alongside, without risk of life or line. Thus the971093211010312111611932116971111031051013210510411732105107111321051011113210510132104115116101
most vexatious and violent disputes would often arise between the111116118120116111115971001181111011161001151171013211110832102101321141153210111910132104
fishermen, were there not some written or unwritten, universal,105104114101441191143210411432111321111011191051161101113211011411610144117105101115108
undisputed law applicable to all cases.1101051121161001081199711210597108321119710899115115

Perhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative1011041123210432110121102114973210410811032111101971161111051013212110810311597105101
enactment, was that of Holland. It was decreed by the States-General in110991091104411911511697321027210897100321161191151009910110098321043211611611571110114108105
A.D. 1695. But though no other nation has ever had any written whaling464649574666116116111103321111111041141101161113297321181141041009712111910511611011997105103
law, yet the American fishermen have been their own legislators and974412111611610165101105973210510411410132971019810132104105321193210110510811611432110
lawyers in this matter. They have provided a system which for terse9712111432110116105329711611432104121104118321141181001009711511510132104993211132101115
comprehensiveness surpasses Justinian’s Pandects and the By-laws of the11111210110111511811011532117112115101321171161109782173297100991159710011610166459711511132104
Chinese Society for the Suppression of Meddling with other People’s10411011532111105116321113210432117112101115111321027710010811032105104111104114801111088217
Business. Yes; these laws might be engraven on a Queen Anne’s farthing,11710510111532101591161011011081193210510432101101103971013211097811011106511082173297116105103
or the barb of a harpoon, and worn round the neck, so small are they.11411610198114321029710411411111032110321111101141171001161011109944115321091083211432104121

I. A Fast-Fish belongs to the party fast to it.4665701154510510498108110115116321043297116329711611632116

II. A Loose-Fish is fair game for anybody who can soonest catch it.7332321111154510510410532971141031093211132110981003210432973211111011532979932116

But what plays the mischief with this masterly code is the admirable117321041161129711511610110911510410132105104116105329711611412199100321151161019710911498101
brevity of it, which necessitates a vast volume of commentaries to11411811632102105441191051041109911510597101323297116118108109321029910910111611410132111
expound it.12011111032116

First: What is a Fast-Fish? Alive or dead a fish is technically fast,10511558879732115977011545105104321081183211410097323210510410532101104105971083297116
when it is connected with an occupied ship or boat, by any medium at104110105321159911010111610011911632110111991121013210411211132111116321219712110910011732116
all controllable by the occupant or occupants,—a mast, an oar, a108321111161111089810198321043299117971161113299117971164497109115449732974497
nine-inch cable, a telegraph wire, or a strand of cobweb, it is all the105101105993297108449711610810397104119114441113232116971001113211111998321161053210832104
same. Likewise a fish is technically fast when it bears a waif, or any97101321051011051019710211532115116991109910812110211532104110105321011143232971023211497121
other recognised symbol of possession; so long as the party waifing it1161013210111111011510011510911132102112115101115111591153211110397321043297116329710211032116
plainly evince their ability at any time to take it alongside, as well1081051083211811010111610111497105105121973211032105101116329710110532108110115100449732101108
as their intention so to do.1151161011141051161101051101153211110046

These are scientific commentaries; but the commentaries of the whalemen10411532114329910111610299991091011161141015998116116101991091011161141013210211610111997101101
themselves sometimes consist in hard words and harder knocks—the104109101118115115109116109115991101051161053297100119114115971001041141013211099115116101
Coke-upon-Littleton of the fist. True, among the more upright and1111011171114510511610111132102116101102115468411744971111031161011091143211210510432110
honorable whalemen allowances are always made for peculiar cases, where11111197108321041081091109710811911010132114321089711510910032111321011171051149911511532104114
it would be an outrageous moral injustice for one party to claim1161191171009832110111116971011173211197321101171169932111321103297116321119997109
possession of a whale previously chased or killed by another party. But111115115105110111323210410832114118111115121999710132114107108101321219711110411411211412132117
others are by no means so scrupulous.116101115971019832111109971151153299117117111115

It will readily be seen that in this case the alleged right of the Duke11611910832101100108321011151013210411610532104115991153210432108101101321051043210211610168107

But why should the King have the head, and the Queen the tail? A reason117321043210411710011610175110329710111610110497449710011610181101110116101116105636511497111
for that, ye lawyers!1113210411632101108119101115

In his treatise on “Queen-Gold,” or Queen-pinmoney, an old King’s Bench1101041151161011161153211082201171014511110082211113211710145105109110121321101111007511082173210199

was written at a time when the black limber bone of the Greenland or9732114116101321169711610932104110116101989710710810910132111101111321043211410110811032114

There are two royal fish so styled by the English law writers—the whale104114321143211932111973210510411532116108100983210432110108115329732114116114821210432104108
and the sturgeon; both royal property under certain limitations, and110321043211611410111032111104114121108112111101116321101013210111610532105105971051104497100
nominally supplying the tenth branch of the crown’s ordinary revenue. I111105971083211711212111032104321011163211411010411132104321141198217321141059712111411811010132
know not that any other author has hinted of the matter; but by1101191101161169732110321161013211710411410411510411010132102116101109116101599811698
inference it seems to me that the sturgeon must be divided in the same11010110199321161151011151163210111697321043211611410111010911532101100118100100105321043297101
way as the whale, the King receiving the highly dense and elastic head97321151161011199710132104321051031149910510510311610110410310832101115321103210811510532101100
peculiar to that fish, which, symbolically regarded, may possibly be10111710511411632104116102115441191051043212198108991081211141031141014410912111211510510832101
humorously grounded upon some presumed congeniality. And thus there117111111115121103111110101321121101151093211411510910099110101105108116466510011611732104114
seems a reason in all things, even in law.1011093232101115110105321083210411011532118110105329746

CHAPTER 92. Ambergris.72806932503210910110310546

Now this ambergris is a very curious substance, and so important as an111321041159798114114115105323210112199114111115115981161101013211032111105112114971169732110
article of commerce, that in 1791 a certain Nantucket-born Captain11410510832102991091019944116973211049573232101116105329711699101451111106711297110
Coffin was examined at the bar of the English House of Commons on that111102110119115101971051013211611610198114111321043211010811532111115321026710911111511132104116
subject. For at that time, and indeed until a comparatively late day,117106994670114973210411611610944971001051001013211010532321111121141161181083297101100121
the precise origin of ambergris remained, like amber itself, a problem1043211499115321141031101113210910110310532101971101003210510197981141051151084497112111108109
to the learned. Though the word ambergris is but the French compound1111161011089711010032104117104116101119114321091011031053211598116116101701019932111112117100
for grey amber, yet the two substances are quite distinct. For amber,111321141219798114321013210432119321171159799115971011131051011001151059946701149798114
though at times found on the sea-coast, is also dug up in some far104117104973210510132111110321101161011159799971163211597115321173211210532111101102114
inland soils, whereas ambergris is never found except upon the sea.1109710011510511532104114973210910110310532115110118114102117100101991123211211011610111597
Besides, amber is a hard, transparent, brittle, odorless substance,1011051014497981141053232971003211411011211411044981051161013210011410111511598116110101
used for mouth-pieces to pipes, for beads and ornaments; but ambergris11510010211410911710411210110132111112112115321113210110032110321149710111659981169798114114115
is soft, waxy, and so highly fragrant and spicy, that it is largely11511510244119120449710011532105104121102971141103211032112994411697321161053297103108
used in perfumery, in pastiles, precious candles, hair-powders, and11510010532101102109114441053297116108115321149911111599110108115329711411211910111532110
pomatum. The Turks use it in cooking, and also carry it to Mecca, for1119711746841018411411511710110532110991111051033211032108111991141211053211177999732111
the same purpose that frankincense is carried to St. Peter’s in Rome.104329710111211411110111697321141101059911010110532971141013211183468011611411510532111101
Some wine merchants drop a few grains into claret, to flavor it.111101119110321019997116321141129710211910397110321101119997101441163210811811410546

I opine, that it is plainly traceable to the first arrival of the3211211044116973211610532108105108321149997108321111161011021141169711411810811132104

That office consists in mincing the horse-pieces of blubber for the104116111102993211111511511510532105991103210432111115451059911511132108981013211132104

intent on bible leaves; what a candidate for an archbishopric, what a1101011161113210510832101118115321041169799110105971011021149732114104105104112105441199732

*Bible leaves! Bible leaves! This is the invariable cry from the mates66981011089710133669810110897101338410532115116101105118114971083211432114109116101109116115
to the mincer. It enjoins him to be careful, and cut his work into as11111610110911010146733211011111032105321119832971011174497100991161041151191143211011197
thin slices as possible, inasmuch as by so doing the business of104110115105101321151121151051084410597109993211598321111001051031161019811511011532102
boiling out the oil is much accelerated, and its quantity considerably11110811032117321043210532115109993299101101971014497100105115113971161163211111510011498121
increased, besides perhaps improving it in quality.110114971014498115100115112114971151051121111051031053211011397105121


CHAPTER 96. The Try-Works.728069325432104321144511110746

Besides her hoisted boats, an American whaler is outwardly10110510132101321111151013211111644973210911499110119971013211511111697100121
distinguished by her try-works. She presents the curious anomaly of the10511611011711510132121104114116121119114115321043211411511011511610199114111115971119712111132104
most solid masonry joining with oak and hemp in constituting the1111161151081001091151101211061051051031191163297321103210111210532111115105117105103116101
completed ship. It is as if from the open field a brick-kiln were111112101101321041123211610532115105321141091161011111013210510832321149945105110119114
transported to her planks.114110112114101321111041141129710746

The try-works are planted between the foremast and mainmast, the most10432114451111073211432108110101321011191013210432111101971169710010910510911544116101109115
roomy part of the deck. The timbers beneath are of a peculiar strength,1111093297116111321043210110732104321059811432101101116321143210297112991089732116101103104
fitted to sustain the weight of an almost solid mass of brick and1051161001163211711610532104321011031161113211097109115321111053297115111321149932110
mortar, some ten feet by eight square, and five in height. The11111611432111101116110102101321211011031161151171144497100102118321101041051044684101
foundation does not penetrate the deck, but the masonry is firmly11111097105110100101321113210110111411632104321011073211732104329711111432115102114108

are kept remarkably clean. Sometimes they are polished with soapstone114321011161141091149710832108974683109116109115116101321143211110510410011911632111112116110
and sand, till they shine within like silver punch-bowls. During the1103297100321051081161013210411032105104110108107321051181141121101049811911532117105103116101

themselves away there for a nap. While employed in polishing them—one104109101118115979732104114321113232974687105101101112111101321101121081151051031161018212110

Nevertheless the sun hides not Virginia’s Dismal Swamp, nor Rome’s1011011161011011151161011151101041001151101168611410510582173210510910883971123211132111101115
